answers.answer: Have you experimented with eating something really cold like ice cream to see whether you get the same reaction?  Perhaps you could try taking you temperature before you eat and after to see whether eating changes your temperature but a noticeable amount?  I read somewhere that in some people even just half a degree difference can bring on the heat intolerance.I don't know whether any of the above is any use, but just thinking outside the box :-)Poppy

question: Hi everyone,I've been in hiding for a while -- trying to just live life. Funny thing is, I'm stressed beyond all reason and my body has been very kind to me. Not bad for someone whose sx are "all a result of stress". :)I do have one symptom that I've been experiencing that I can't explain.I get really bad nerve pain in my arms and back after eating. It's that electric nerve pain where even air on your skin is excruciating. Does anyone else experience that?Dr Google says its diabetes 2, but drs have ruled that out and I have zip as far as risk factors.I seem to recall reading some obscure comment somewhere that it could be related to the heat increase in your system from carb/sugar intake...not like diabetes, but more of a paresthesia brought on by heat intolerance, like one would get from exercise or a fever. But that sounds kind of far-fetched...Any ideas?Thanks!
title: Unusual symptom
